attributes.title: The Impact of Mindfulness-Based Resilience Training on Stress-Related Biological, Behavioral, and Health-Related Outcomes in Law Enforcement Officers
attributes.description: The Impact of Mindfulness-Based Resilience Training on Relationships between Stressor Exposure and Perceived Stress in Law Enforcement Officers

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: The Impact of Mindfulness-Based Resilience Training on Relationships between Stressor Exposure and Perceived Stress in Law Enforcement Officers

other.value:
Note that we have already collected all data and conducted preliminary exploratory factor analysis of work events data. We have not yet conducted any analyses of these events in relation to other variables specified in our hypotheses.

Six items of FFMQ-SF for Cohort 1 were missing at baseline due to an error in entering questions into our online survey. Specifically, one item in “observing” subscale (“20. I notice visual elements in art or nature, such as colors, shapes, textures, or patterns of light and shadow”), two items in “acting with awareness” subscale (“22. I do jobs or tasks automatically without being aware of what I’m doing”, “23. I find myself doing things without paying attention”), two items in “non-judgment” subscale (“19. I think some of my emotions are bad or inappropriate and I shouldn’t feel them”, “24. I disapprove of myself when I have illogical ideas”), and one item in “non-reactivity” subscale (“21. When I have distressing thoughts or images, I just notice them and let them go”). This mistake was identified and corrected before subsequent assessments. Rather than abandoning data from the FFMQ-SF for Cohort 1, we will impute missing data using the mean score of items collected for each subscale.

Different police agencies and different job characteristics (i.e., shift, title, years of experience) within an agency are all likely to bear on exposure to different stressors, how these stressors are appraised, or available coping resources. Although we don’t have specific hypotheses, we will conduct secondary analyses considering each of these factors as covariates.

In additional exploratory analyses, we will test whether mindfulness training leads to lower levels of stress exposure for each the 3 components indicated above. While we do not think there will be objective changes in stress exposure for the intervention vs. control group, it is possible that this training may lead to a subjective shift in perceived exposure in addition to the predicted reduction in perceived stress.

sample.value: We planned to collect data from 120 participants at each of 3 assessments (with an estimated 10% attrition by T3). This number was determined as part of the larger study design for the overarching clinical trial. Our actual enrollment total was 115 participants at T1, 109 participants at T2, and 104 participants at T3.

analyses.value:
All analyses will involve a fixed effects covariate of study Cohort (see “Analyses” section of an additional preregistration for this project: https://osf.io/mqnga).

Using the lmer library in R, we will use linear regression models to test H1 and linear mixed effects models to test H2 and H3. Null hypothesis testing will be conducted with p = 0.05 for each of the hypotheses.

H1: 
lmer(Perceived stress ~ Exposure + Days + Cohort + (1 + Days | Subject))
This model will be conducted both using the average of all 8 items for exposure/perceived stress, and for each of the 3 components identified in our exploratory factor analysis. We expect a significant effect of Exposure on Perceived stress, indicating that greater exposure to different types of work stressors is associated with greater perceived stress.

H2:
lmer(Perceived stress ~ Exposure*Mindfulness + Days + Cohort + (1 + Days | Subject))
lmer(Perceived stress ~ Exposure*Resilience + Days + Cohort + (1 + Days | Subject))
We expect significant Exposure*Mindfulness and Exposure*Resilience interactions, such that individuals with higher levels of trait mindfulness and resilience will show a relatively weaker relationship between stressor exposure and perceived stress. Additionally, both total scores of FFMQ-SF and total scores of each facet will be tested separately.

H3: 
lmer(Perceived stress ~ Group*Time*Exposure + Days +Cohort + (1+Days | Class/Subject) + (1+ Days | Time))
We hypothesize a significant Group*Time*Exposure interaction, such that the relation between stress exposure and perceived stress will be statistically weakened in the intervention group relative to the waitlist control group following mindfulness training. 
Group will be a dummy variable (1 = mindfulness group, 0 = control group). Subject will be nested in Class (where class is a random effect corresponding to 4 different classes that participants in the mindfulness group are assigned to, with a 5th “class” for the waitlist control group). Time will be a crossed random effect.

outliers.value: For self-report measures, outliers will be defined as observations greater than 3 SDs from the mean and they will be excluded. Participants who have fewer than 4 valid work stress surveys for a given work week will be excluded from analyses for that time point.

dependent.value:
1. Daily stress exposure will be assessed using 8 questions about exposure to categories of stressors typically experienced by police officers. These items were drawn from an original 10-item survey developed by our study team in consultation with local police officers. Exploratory factory analysis suggested a 3-component factor structure from these 8 items that assesses three categories of stressors that police officers may be exposed to on a daily basis. Component 1 assesses less frequent line-of-duty incidents involving arrests, exposure to trauma, and bodily harm, component 2 assesses routine daily stressors including paperwork, staffing shortages, and routine calls for service, and component 3 assesses interpersonal stressors from leadership and interactions with coworkers. Higher average scores of each category indicate more stress exposure (0 = No exposure/did not experience, 1 = Less exposure than a typical day, 2 = About the same exposure as a typical day, 3 = More exposure than a typical day). Both the average score of all categories and each category score will be used in analyses.

2. Daily perceived stress will be assessed using an 8-item subscale of work events. Items are the same as for the daily stress exposure subscale, but the question for each item is “How much stress did you experience due to this event”. Higher scores indicate greater experienced stress (0 = no exposure to this event/no stress at all, 10 = extreme amount of stress). Both the average score across all categories and each category score will be used in analyses.

3. Overall daily perceived stress will be assessed by a single item comparing the recently completed work day to a typical day at work, with a possible range of 1 (much less stressful) to 5 (much more stressful).

4. Trait mindfulness will be assessed by the Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire-Short Form (FFMQ-SF; Bohlmeijer, Ten Klooster, Fledderus, Veehof, & Baer, 2011). FFMQ-SF is a 24-item scale assessing different facets of trait mindfulness including observing (4 items), describing (5 items), acting with awareness (5 items), non-judging of (5 items) and non-reactivity to inner experiences (5 items). Both total score of each facet and a sum of all facets will be used for analyses. Higher total scores indicate more capacity in that mindfulness skill (1 = never or very rarely true, 5 = very often or always true).

5. Resilience will be assessed by the Brief Resilience Scale (BRS; Smith et al., 2008). The 6-item BRS assesses general capacity to bounce back from adversities. There are three reverse scored items. A higher total score indicates more resilience for general situation (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree), with a possible range of 6-30.

Participants were asked to complete the stress questionnaire (variables 1-3) at the end of each work day during a work week, which ranged from 3-7 days. The mindfulness and resilience measures were collected at a baseline visit prior to this work week.

conditions.value: A total of 115 police officers were recruited from Dane County (WI) law enforcement agencies. Following the completion of baseline assessments, 114 participants were randomly assigned to two conditions: (1) the mMBRT (Madison-Mindfulness Based Resilience Training) group received an 8-week mindfulness intervention adapted specifically for law enforcement officers and (2) A waitlist control group received no intervention until after all study procedures. For additional details on these groups and randomization procedures, see (https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03488875).

hypothesis.value:
H1: In a sample of Midwestern U.S. law enforcement officers, within-subject differences in daily stress exposure will be positively linked to perceived stress 

H2: Trait mindfulness and resilience will moderate the association between stress exposure and perceived stress

H3: Participation in an 8-week mindfulness intervention, relative to waitlist control, will lead to relative decoupling or attenuation of the association between stress exposure and perceived stress.

attributes.title: A Traumatic Dissonance Theory of Perpetrator-Related Distress
attributes.description: A theory and preliminary measure of one potential mechanism of perpetrator-related distress.

summary.value:
Materials and data are included for the study, which is aimed at developing a theoretical basis for understanding the mechanism of psychological distress resulting from perceived perpetration. It is hypothesized that unresolved dissonance relating to a violation of one’s symbolic source of self-esteem and meaning, i.e. one’s belief system, represents a traumatic experience that can produce significant psychological distress. Participants (N = 429) were recruited online and include subsamples of military, police, and nonmilitary participants. 

Qualtrics survey includes all measured variables. Data file excludes qualitative responses to open-ended question of the Traumatic Dissonance Scale (TDS) due to the sensitive/personal nature of responses (variable names included in separate txt file). CFA output (mplus syntax is included in output) is provided for the final 9-item, 3-factor model of the TDS. Latent profile analysis identified four respondent classes that differ in mean responses to the three TDS dimensions: class probability/membership variables were created and merged with PCL data in order to run subsequent ANOVA to test the relationship between TDS class membership and PTSD symptoms severity (PCL total scores). Merged data set included.

attributes.title: Developmental trajectories of perceptual narrowing among monolingual and bilingual infants
Negated adjectives and politeness
attributes.description: Investigating the role of face-management in the interpretation of negated antonyms.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Negated adjectives and politeness: disentangling adjectival polarity and face-threatening potential

other.value: We will investigate the role of participant gender as an exploratory analysis. in addition, we will compare morphologically-complex and simple antonymic pairs.

sample.value: We will collect 60 participants in total (30 across two experimental lists). Each participant completes 20 trials (and 8 additional filler trials). The resulting number of critical observations is 1200.

analyses.value: We will run an ordinal mixed model including a main effect of polarity and random effects for participants and items.

outliers.value: Participants who answer incoherently in the filler trials will be excluded from further analyses (if they answer with 5, 6, or 7 in more than 4 filler trials).

dependent.value: The dependent variable is the degree of negative strengthening. We will measure the degree of negative strengthening by using a 7-point Likert scale anchored at the negated adjective (1) and its antonym (7).

conditions.value: We have one factor, polarity, with two levels (positive, negative). We will test 20 positive adjectives and their corresponding negative antonyms. Each participant will see all conditions in a Latin square design (across two experimental lists).

hypothesis.value:
What are the contributions of adjectival polarity and face-threatening potential to the interpretation of negated gradable adjectives? This study investigates whether the polarity asymmetry of negative strengthening (Ruytenbeek et al. 2017) – with negated positive polarity adjectives being more likely to be strengthened than negated negative polarity adjectives – can be explained by face-management considerations. 
The explanation of the polarity asymmetry in terms of face-management (following Brown and Levinson, 1987 and Horn, 1989) predicts that the asymmetry should be reversed in ‘non-ordinary’ contexts in which it is the assertion of a positive polarity adjective – and not that of its antonym – to constitute a face-threatening act. The study investigates this prediction by assessing the degree of negative strengthening of positive and negative polarity adjectives in non-ordinary contexts.

attributes.title: Stress beliefs in patients suffering from mental disorders: The reliability and validity of the Beliefs About Stress Scale (BASS) in psychotherapy outpatients

q1.value: Stress beliefs in patients suffering from mental disorders: The reliability and validity of the Beliefs About Stress Scale (BASS) in psychotherapy outpatients

q2.value: Johannes Andreas Christoph Laferton, Christina J. Mueller, Nikola Stenzel, Susanne Fischer

q3.value:
Recent research has provided evidence for the effects of stress beliefs  on mental and physical health outcomes in general population samples, university student samples and workers. However, the role of stress beliefs in the context of mental health disorders is still unclear. Some laboratory studies inidcate that stress beliefs might play a role in patients with mental health disorders such as social anxiety disorder. However, (to our knowledge) outside of the laboratory it remains unclear wheter and to what extend the construct of stress beliefs does play a role in patients with mental health disorders.  Therefore this study sets out to validate the Beliefs about Stress Scale, a self report questionnaire to assess stress beliefs, in a sample of routine care outpatient psychotherapy patients. Furhter, this study aims to assess the association of stress beliefs with mental health symptoms and their treatment:
3.	Research Questions 
Is the BASS a reliable and valid psychometric questionnaire to assess stress beliefs in patients with mental disorders? 
3.1	Can the 3-dimensional factor structure of the BASS (negative, positive, and controllability beliefs) that emerged in a healthy population of university students (Laferton, Stenzel & Fischer, 2018) be replicated in patients with mental disorders?
3.2	Are the BASS subscales reliable within psychotherapy outpatients?
3.3	Can measures of discriminant validity of BASS subscales with optimism, pessimism and trait negative affectivity that were reported in Laferton et al., (2018) be replicated? 
3.4	Are more negative, less positive and controllability stress beliefs associated with increased psychopathological symptoms?
3.5	Do cognitive behavioral and psychodynamic outpatient treatment change stress beliefs?  
3.6	Is the change of stress beliefs during psychotherapy outpatient treatment associated with changes in mental health symptoms? 
3.7	Do stress beliefs predict treatment outcome in outpatient psychotherapy?

q4.value:
4.1	We hypothesize that a confirmatory factor analysis of the model formerly reported in the study of Laferton et al. (2018), with three correlated factors (positive stress beliefs, negative stress beliefs and controllability beliefs) will yield a good model fit to the data of the here investigated sample.
4.2	We expect to confirm internal consistency values as reported in Laferton et al. (2018).
4.3	 We expect to replicate findings of Laferton et al. (2018) regarding validity measures such that negative stress beliefs are negatively correlated to optimism and positively correlated to pessimism and negative affectivity (all small to medium effect sizes); positive stress beliefs are positively correlated to optimism and negatively correlated to pessimism and negative affectivity (all small to medium effect sizes); controllability beliefs are positively correlated to optimism and negatively correlated to pessimism and negative affectivity (medium to large effect sizes).
4.4	At assessment before treatment, higher negative stress beliefs, lower positive stress beliefs and controllability beliefs are related to a higher global score of psychopathological symptoms, and especially to depression and anxiety symptoms.
4.5	Do patients’ negative, positive and controllability stress beliefs (BASS) change during outpatient psychotherapy treatment (pre to post treatment). Do cognitive behavior therapy and psychodynamic therapy differentially influence changes in stress beliefs? 
4.6	Differences in BASS subscales measured before and after treatment predict changes in a global score of psychopathological symptoms, and especially depression and anxiety symptoms.
4.7	Negative, positive and controllability stress beliefs (BASS) predict changes in psychopathological symptoms, and especially depression and anxiety symptoms.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
14	Study type
Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. 

15	Blinding
n.a.

16	Study design
Cross-sectional (intake) and longitudinal study of patients at intake and end of routine care outpatient psychotherapy treatment

17	Randomization
n.a.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: This study will be conducted using data collected as part of the routine assessment of a large outpatient psychotherapy clinic. Data were collected by treating psychotherapist as part of their clinical routine. Therapists were blind to study hypothesis. None of the authors were involved in data collection. The authors will not have access to the data before submission of preregistration.

question.value:
The BASS was added to the routine psychometric assessment of an outpatient psychotherapy clinic in November 2016. The outpatient clinic offers routine clinical care treatment of either cognitive behavioral or psychodynamic psychotherapy. Patients are assigned to psychodynamic or cognitive behavioral therapy based on patients’ preference and therapist availability. All treating psychotherapist are in advanced training for either cognitive behavioral therapy or psychodynamic therapy and are supervised by federal licensed and experienced psychotherapists. All patients admitted for treatment at the outpatient clinic undergo baseline assessment prior to treatment conducted by their assigned psychotherapist. Baseline assessment includes the collection of basic and demographic data, application of self-report questionnaires, clinician diagnosis and clinician rating scales. After their final treatment session all patients undergo discharge assessment as part of routine clinical procedure conducted by their treating psychotherapist. This again includes self-report questionnaires, clinician diagnosis and clinician rating scales. 
All patients undergo written and verbal informed consent procedures provided by their psychotherapist, which includes information on potential scientific use of their data.

q13.value: Sample size estimations are based on the confirmatory factor analysis performed with the baseline data (at intake).

q14.value: In order to replicate the 3-factor structure of the BASS, of which two factors consist of only three or four indicators (BASS-P and BASS-C) and some of the BASS-N indicators have factor loadings around .50 (see Laferton et al., 2018), following (Marsh, Hau, Balla, & Grayson, 1998; Wolf, Harrington, Clark, & Miller, 2013) we aimed for a baseline sample size of N = 450. Allowing for 15% of patients not providing data on the BASS we aimed to assess 518 patients at intake for psychotherapy.

q15.value: Based on the patient turnover of the previous years (around 170 intakes per year), we estimated 37 months of data collection to reach the sample size needed for confirmatory factor analysis.

question.value:
12.1 Demographic variables of participants (at baseline assessment): 
•	age
•	gender
12.2 Basic data regarding therapy
•	ICD-10 mental disorder diagnosis
•	Type of therapy (Cognitive Behavior therapy; psychodynamic therapy)
•	Type of therapy ending (1= regular; 2 = no more payment granted by health insurance; 3 = premature ending of therapy)
•	Number of sessions
12.3 Standardized Scales (German versions) 
•	Positive stress beliefs, negative stress beliefs, controllability beliefs (Beliefs About Stress Scale BASS, Laferton et al., 2018)
•	Optimism, pessimism (Life Orientation Test Revised LOT-R; Herzberg, Glaesmer & Hoyer, 2006)
•	Global symptom rating score, depression, anxiety (ICD-10 Symptom Rating ISR; Tritt, von Heymann, Zaudig, Zacharias, Söllner & Loew, 2008)
•	Negative Affectivity (Personality Inventory for DSM 5 PID-5; Zimmermann et al., 2014)

18.1 For hypothesis 1, a confirmatory factor analysis using structural equation modeling (SEM) will be carried out on BASS items that were collected in the beginning of each patients’ therapy. The factor structure that was identified in an exploratory factor analysis by Laferton et al. (2018) is supposed to be replicated in this confirmatory factor analysis with items 1-8 loading on factor 1 (negative stress beliefs); items 9-11 loading on factor 2 (controllability) and items 12-15 loading on factor three (positive stress beliefs). A model with three correlated factors will be tested. Chi square, root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA) and standardized root mean square residual (SRMR) will be investigated as model fit criteria. 
18.2 To confirm reliability measures, Cronbach’s alpha will be computed separately for each subscale (positive stress beliefs, negative stress beliefs, controllability beliefs) as internal consistency score
18.3 To quantify discriminant validity, bivariate correlations will be computed of BASS subscales with optimism and pessimism scores of LOT-R and negative affectivity score of PID-5.
18.4 Bivariate correlations will be computed between BASS subscales and the global symptom rating score of the ISR, as well as depression and anxiety subscales of the ISR (3 x 3 = 9 correlations). 
18.5 A repeated measures analysis of variance will be carried out on BASS subscale (negative, positive, controllability; = 3 models) scores with time (before vs after treatment) as within-subject factor and type of therapy (cognitive behaviour therapy vs psychodynamic therapy) as between-subjects factor and their interaction effect among patients that completed treatment regularly.
18.6 Multiple regression analyses will be carried out in order to determine whether changes in BASS subscales predict changes in psychopathological symptoms. Changes in BASS subscales will serve as predictors. Age and gender of patients will be included as covariates. Dependent variables will be changes in global symptom rating score (ISR), changes in depression symptoms (ISR subscale depression) and changes in anxiety symptoms (anxiety subscale of the ISR). To control for multicollinearity, separate regression models will be estimated for each BASS subscale (3x3 = 9 models).
18.7 Multiple regression analyses will be carried out in order to determine whether BASS subscales predict changes in psychopathological symptoms. BASS subscales will serve as predictors. Age and gender of patients will be included as covariates. Dependent variables will be changes in global symptom rating score (ISR), changes in depression symptoms (ISR subscale depression) and changes in anxiety symptoms (anxiety subscale of the ISR). To control for multicollinearity, separate regression models will be estimated for each BASS subscale (3x3 = 9 models).

19 Transformations
n.a.

20 Follow-up analyses
n.a.

21 Inference criteria

For model fit criteria in hypothesis 1, a good model fit will be indicated by a non-significant Chi-square statistic, and SRMS and RSMEA values below .05.

p values of .05 will generally be used as significance indicators. Regarding the non-confirmatory hypothesis (H4.4 to 4.7) Bonferroni correction will be used to control for multiple testing within each hypothesis.

22	Data exclusion


23	Missing data
Participants with any missing values on baseline BASS will be excluded from analysis. Further, participants with >50% over all missing values per assessment time point will be excluded for the respective assessment time point. Missing <= 20% values per questionnaire sub-scale will be imputed by the mean of the respective subscale. Higher missing values per subscale will lead to missing data on the respective subscale for the participant.
Longitudinal hypothesis will only be evaluated among participants who completed therapy. We will explore potential selective drop out (patient that are not still in therapy but did not provide follow-up assessment) regarding BASS and ISR. Only participants with complete data sets on both ISR and BASS at baseline and follow up will be used.

registration_responses.q1: Stress beliefs in patients suffering from mental disorders: The reliability and validity of the Beliefs About Stress Scale (BASS) in psychotherapy outpatients
registration_responses.q2: Johannes Andreas Christoph Laferton, Christina J. Mueller, Nikola Stenzel, Susanne Fischer
registration_responses.q3:
Recent research has provided evidence for the effects of stress beliefs  on mental and physical health outcomes in general population samples, university student samples and workers. However, the role of stress beliefs in the context of mental health disorders is still unclear. Some laboratory studies inidcate that stress beliefs might play a role in patients with mental health disorders such as social anxiety disorder. However, (to our knowledge) outside of the laboratory it remains unclear wheter and to what extend the construct of stress beliefs does play a role in patients with mental health disorders.  Therefore this study sets out to validate the Beliefs about Stress Scale, a self report questionnaire to assess stress beliefs, in a sample of routine care outpatient psychotherapy patients. Furhter, this study aims to assess the association of stress beliefs with mental health symptoms and their treatment:
3.	Research Questions 
Is the BASS a reliable and valid psychometric questionnaire to assess stress beliefs in patients with mental disorders? 
3.1	Can the 3-dimensional factor structure of the BASS (negative, positive, and controllability beliefs) that emerged in a healthy population of university students (Laferton, Stenzel & Fischer, 2018) be replicated in patients with mental disorders?
3.2	Are the BASS subscales reliable within psychotherapy outpatients?
3.3	Can measures of discriminant validity of BASS subscales with optimism, pessimism and trait negative affectivity that were reported in Laferton et al., (2018) be replicated? 
3.4	Are more negative, less positive and controllability stress beliefs associated with increased psychopathological symptoms?
3.5	Do cognitive behavioral and psychodynamic outpatient treatment change stress beliefs?  
3.6	Is the change of stress beliefs during psychotherapy outpatient treatment associated with changes in mental health symptoms? 
3.7	Do stress beliefs predict treatment outcome in outpatient psychotherapy?
registration_responses.q4:
4.1	We hypothesize that a confirmatory factor analysis of the model formerly reported in the study of Laferton et al. (2018), with three correlated factors (positive stress beliefs, negative stress beliefs and controllability beliefs) will yield a good model fit to the data of the here investigated sample.
4.2	We expect to confirm internal consistency values as reported in Laferton et al. (2018).
4.3	 We expect to replicate findings of Laferton et al. (2018) regarding validity measures such that negative stress beliefs are negatively correlated to optimism and positively correlated to pessimism and negative affectivity (all small to medium effect sizes); positive stress beliefs are positively correlated to optimism and negatively correlated to pessimism and negative affectivity (all small to medium effect sizes); controllability beliefs are positively correlated to optimism and negatively correlated to pessimism and negative affectivity (medium to large effect sizes).
4.4	At assessment before treatment, higher negative stress beliefs, lower positive stress beliefs and controllability beliefs are related to a higher global score of psychopathological symptoms, and especially to depression and anxiety symptoms.
4.5	Do patients’ negative, positive and controllability stress beliefs (BASS) change during outpatient psychotherapy treatment (pre to post treatment). Do cognitive behavior therapy and psychodynamic therapy differentially influence changes in stress beliefs? 
4.6	Differences in BASS subscales measured before and after treatment predict changes in a global score of psychopathological symptoms, and especially depression and anxiety symptoms.
4.7	Negative, positive and controllability stress beliefs (BASS) predict changes in psychopathological symptoms, and especially depression and anxiety symptoms.

registration_responses.q14: In order to replicate the 3-factor structure of the BASS, of which two factors consist of only three or four indicators (BASS-P and BASS-C) and some of the BASS-N indicators have factor loadings around .50 (see Laferton et al., 2018), following (Marsh, Hau, Balla, & Grayson, 1998; Wolf, Harrington, Clark, & Miller, 2013) we aimed for a baseline sample size of N = 450. Allowing for 15% of patients not providing data on the BASS we aimed to assess 518 patients at intake for psychotherapy.
registration_responses.q15: Based on the patient turnover of the previous years (around 170 intakes per year), we estimated 37 months of data collection to reach the sample size needed for confirmatory factor analysis.

registration_responses.q12.question:
The BASS was added to the routine psychometric assessment of an outpatient psychotherapy clinic in November 2016. The outpatient clinic offers routine clinical care treatment of either cognitive behavioral or psychodynamic psychotherapy. Patients are assigned to psychodynamic or cognitive behavioral therapy based on patients’ preference and therapist availability. All treating psychotherapist are in advanced training for either cognitive behavioral therapy or psychodynamic therapy and are supervised by federal licensed and experienced psychotherapists. All patients admitted for treatment at the outpatient clinic undergo baseline assessment prior to treatment conducted by their assigned psychotherapist. Baseline assessment includes the collection of basic and demographic data, application of self-report questionnaires, clinician diagnosis and clinician rating scales. After their final treatment session all patients undergo discharge assessment as part of routine clinical procedure conducted by their treating psychotherapist. This again includes self-report questionnaires, clinician diagnosis and clinician rating scales. 
All patients undergo written and verbal informed consent procedures provided by their psychotherapist, which includes information on potential scientific use of their data.
registration_responses.q17.question:
12.1 Demographic variables of participants (at baseline assessment): 
•	age
•	gender
12.2 Basic data regarding therapy
•	ICD-10 mental disorder diagnosis
•	Type of therapy (Cognitive Behavior therapy; psychodynamic therapy)
•	Type of therapy ending (1= regular; 2 = no more payment granted by health insurance; 3 = premature ending of therapy)
•	Number of sessions
12.3 Standardized Scales (German versions) 
•	Positive stress beliefs, negative stress beliefs, controllability beliefs (Beliefs About Stress Scale BASS, Laferton et al., 2018)
•	Optimism, pessimism (Life Orientation Test Revised LOT-R; Herzberg, Glaesmer & Hoyer, 2006)
•	Global symptom rating score, depression, anxiety (ICD-10 Symptom Rating ISR; Tritt, von Heymann, Zaudig, Zacharias, Söllner & Loew, 2008)
•	Negative Affectivity (Personality Inventory for DSM 5 PID-5; Zimmermann et al., 2014)
registration_responses.q19.question:
18.1 For hypothesis 1, a confirmatory factor analysis using structural equation modeling (SEM) will be carried out on BASS items that were collected in the beginning of each patients’ therapy. The factor structure that was identified in an exploratory factor analysis by Laferton et al. (2018) is supposed to be replicated in this confirmatory factor analysis with items 1-8 loading on factor 1 (negative stress beliefs); items 9-11 loading on factor 2 (controllability) and items 12-15 loading on factor three (positive stress beliefs). A model with three correlated factors will be tested. Chi square, root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA) and standardized root mean square residual (SRMR) will be investigated as model fit criteria. 
18.2 To confirm reliability measures, Cronbach’s alpha will be computed separately for each subscale (positive stress beliefs, negative stress beliefs, controllability beliefs) as internal consistency score
18.3 To quantify discriminant validity, bivariate correlations will be computed of BASS subscales with optimism and pessimism scores of LOT-R and negative affectivity score of PID-5.
18.4 Bivariate correlations will be computed between BASS subscales and the global symptom rating score of the ISR, as well as depression and anxiety subscales of the ISR (3 x 3 = 9 correlations). 
18.5 A repeated measures analysis of variance will be carried out on BASS subscale (negative, positive, controllability; = 3 models) scores with time (before vs after treatment) as within-subject factor and type of therapy (cognitive behaviour therapy vs psychodynamic therapy) as between-subjects factor and their interaction effect among patients that completed treatment regularly.
18.6 Multiple regression analyses will be carried out in order to determine whether changes in BASS subscales predict changes in psychopathological symptoms. Changes in BASS subscales will serve as predictors. Age and gender of patients will be included as covariates. Dependent variables will be changes in global symptom rating score (ISR), changes in depression symptoms (ISR subscale depression) and changes in anxiety symptoms (anxiety subscale of the ISR). To control for multicollinearity, separate regression models will be estimated for each BASS subscale (3x3 = 9 models).
18.7 Multiple regression analyses will be carried out in order to determine whether BASS subscales predict changes in psychopathological symptoms. BASS subscales will serve as predictors. Age and gender of patients will be included as covariates. Dependent variables will be changes in global symptom rating score (ISR), changes in depression symptoms (ISR subscale depression) and changes in anxiety symptoms (anxiety subscale of the ISR). To control for multicollinearity, separate regression models will be estimated for each BASS subscale (3x3 = 9 models).

q1.value: Study 1: SDO, Belief and Science, and Speciesism: the moderated role of gender (erratum)

q3.value:
As you will probably notice, the first preregistration on the project page (https://osf.io/n27zj) is mentioning in the title, variables that are not presented in the preregistration. In fact, this preregistration is a copy/paste of another preregistration from another project (https://osf.io/ythv5) and the real preregistration has not been loaded. You will find below the real preregistration, I'm using the OSF template to link to this preregistration the original preregistration that were done using the AsPredicted template and on MSword.

This study is a part of a larger data collection where we decided to split our data set into two equal parts to investigate two different questions.
In this first study we are interested in the linked between four variables: the SDO, the Belief in Science and the Speciesism and the moderating effect of gender.
In the second study (that you will find here: https://osf.io/jdzuf/ and to which the other preregistration of this page refers) we are interested on the effect of the Speciesism on the both perception of emotions and suffering among animals and the mediating role of the Empathy.

q4.value:
This project is a correlational study where we will investigate how certain variables may interact together and compose a model
In this study, we will first investigate the link between Social Dominance Orientation (SDO), Speciesism (S) and Belief in Science (BS) and we first expect a positive link among these three variables.
Considering that males tend to have greater SDO-levels than females, have stronger attitudes against animal concern (i.e., less vegetarian), and have lower empathy-level, we are also expecting to find a moderator effect of the gender of participant on each of these three links (SDO-BS, SDO-S; S-BS). We presume that being a male would accentuate the links between our variables of interest when being a woman would attenuate these links.

q11.value: Regarding an experimental study, we made a large data collection but we regarding some a-priori defined (such as fro example psychology/biology/medicine/chemistry... students), we excluded a lot of participants. We thus decided to perform two correlational studies with these data.

question.value:
Participants were recruited using Facebook promotions, press and flyers and the data collection lasted 1 year and half. As explained before, the data collection was originally for another purpose, a first online questionnaire before an experimental task in a lab.

In this study, participants are only participants who were excluded for the experimental task or participants who did not show up for the second experimental task.

-Social Dominance Orientation (Sidanius & Pratto): 8 items, validated scale, french translation, 5 points likert scale

-Speciesism (Caviola, et al., 2018): 6 items, validated scale, french translation, 5 points likert scale

-Belief in Science: 4 items, developed in our lab and has a great internal consistency regarding previous results on other studies, 5 points likert scale

-Sexe: Male/Female

First, we will assess if our variables of interest are well related to each other, we will perform a set of different Bravais Pearson correlational analysis between:
-SDO and S
-S and BS
-S and SDO

Then, performing regression analysis we will investigate for our three links (SDO-S; S-BS; BS-SDO) if we can find an interaction effect of the gender.

q22.value:
Upstream Cleaning-data:
- As the survey was done on internet and mainly diffused via a Facebook promotion post, we will use an item "please copy your given confidential code in the blank space below" as a way to remove bots (using this question as a captcha). 
- We will also remove every participants who did not complete the questionnaire while excluding every participants who did not complete the last item
- We will also use the previous point as an attention check and remove participants who did not correctly report their codes. It will also allow us to remove all the tests who were made by experimenters, testing if the questionnaire was well working (instruction was always done to never report the presented confidentiality code during a test).
- As this questionnaire is a part of another project (more details in the procedure of the OSF page), in order to not analyze two times the same data we will also exclude upstream data from participants that are already been selected for the other project.

Specific exclusion regarding the study:
- We will apply an interpolation procedure to deal with missing values if less that 25 % of a scale has missing values. If a scale has more than 25% missing values, the participant will be discarded on that measure (i.e., SDO, S, BS)

q25.value:
More variables were presented on the questionnaire because of the original purpose of this survey (i.e., a later experimental task), but in this study we will only look at our 4 chosen variables (i.e., S, SDO, BS, gender) and some of the others will be analyzed in the second project.

This study is a part of a larger data-collection and we decided to compose two independent studies with each half of the data collected. 
This study is independent from the other but to see the other study, please refer to this link: https://osf.io/jdzuf/
Data were collected and cleaned (remove of bots, remove of participants/experimenters who failed the "attention task" and remove of participants who already did the experimental lab task) but no analyses regarding any variables were performed.

We extracted data from a questionnaire, which is still running, and continue to collect data and we are planning to continue to collect data until summer 2021 and we may make a second study, investigating or not the same ideas (following the results of this study or not).

attributes.title: Peer stressors and physical health symptoms during adolescents

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Peer stressors and physical health symptoms during adolescents

other.value: Although no study has been published using this dataset yet, data on peer victimization and somatic symptoms have been analyzed and presented at the European Association for Research on Adolescence (EARA )biennial meeting in 2018 (de Bruine et al., 2018). These analyses indicated that peer victimization is associated with somatic symptoms at both the between- and the within-person level. However, it should be noted that the current physical health outcome is different than the one previously examined, as sleep quality and a general health item  will be added to the overall outcome construct of physical health symptoms. For peer preference and peer popularity no associations were previously explored or analyzed.

sample.value:
Data from this study will be drawn from a larger longitudinal project aimed at examining the effects of peer experiences on adolescents’ immune system functioning and health outcomes. This project consists of a multi-wave design that includes 4 time points, with approximately 6 months between consecutive assessments. Data collection begun in November/December 2016 (Time 1), when adolescents were in the fall of the first year of secondary school, and ended in June 2018 (Time 4), just before the end of the second year of secondary school. Approximately half of the targeted adolescents (n = 216) took part in the study at Time 1; retention rate between consecutive assessments was high (> 90%). Adolescents who did not participate at Time 1 of the study add the opportunity to join the study at Time 2, 3 or 4. For this study, adolescents were included if they participated in at least one of the four waves. This resulted in an analytic sample of 233 adolescents who at baseline were approximately 12 years old.
Sample size of the larger longitudinal project was based on a priori power calculation. This calculation indicated that a sample size of 200 would provide 80% power at an alpha level of 0.5% to detect significant effects, including moderating effects, at a medium effect size.

analyses.value:
Data cleaning and preparation. To examine within-person associations, before conducting the analyses the study variables will be transformed in the following way. First, within-person mean (Level 2) peer victimization, peer preference and peer popularity will be defined as an adolescent unique sample-standardized person mean across all four assessments. Second, within-person deviations in (Level 1) peer victimization, peer preference and peer popularity will be calculated as a given assessment’s value minus an adolescent’s unique person mean across all assessments divided by the adolescent’s unique standard deviation (i.e., person-standardized). Eventually, the study variables will be inspected to examine their distribution and the presence of (extreme) outliers. If needed, highly skewed variables (e.g., within person mean levels of peer victimization) will be (log-) transformed and extreme outliers (i.e., > 3 SD from the mean) will be winsorized to the highest value in the distribution. 

Main research questions. 
We will use a multilevel modeling approach to examine all research questions.
 
To examine the unique associations of peer victimization, peer preference and peer popularity on physical health (i.e., unique-effect models), we will specify 2 multivariate multilevel regression models with time at level 1 and person at level 2. First, we will predict physical health by between (e.g., within-person mean peer victimization), and within person (e.g., within-person deviations over time of peer victimization) levels of peer victimization, peer preference and peer popularity (Model 1). Second, we will examine a quadratic trend of peer popularity (Model 2). 

Subsequently, to explore whether peer preference interacts with peer popularity (i.e., interaction-effect model; Model 3),we will add the interaction term between the two types of peer status at both the between and within level (note that in this model, the quadratic effect of peer popularity will not be included)

Finally, to test a cumulative risk model we will use peer victimization, peer acceptance, rejection and unpopularity as risk variables to create a cumulative risk metric score. We will not include peer popularity in the cumulative score, as it remains unclear to what extent  high levels of peer popularity is a risk factor/stressor (this will be explored in Model 2 ). In line with research on cumulative risk (Evans et al., 2013) each risk variable will be dichotomized to reflect either absence (= “0”) or presence (=“1”) of the peer stressor. With regard to peer victimization, in line with previous research (Oldenburg et al., 2015; Solberg & Olweus, 2003) adolescents will be classified as victims (= “1”) when they score 3 or higher on at least 1 experience of peer victimization (i.e., one of the 13 items); adolescents who score 1 (= “never”) or 2 (“one/two times”) will be classified as not victimized. With this approach, adolescents who are exposed to one or more peer victimization form at least three times a month will be classified as victims. For peer acceptance adolescents will be classified as experiencing risk (i.e., “1”) if their scores fall at or below the 25th percentile (reflecting 0/1 nominations). For peer rejection and peer unpopularity adolescents will be classified as experiencing risk (i.e., “1”) if their scores are above the 75th percentile (reflecting 2 or more nomination; Gerard & Buehler, 2004; Hebron et al., 2017). 

All models will be adjusted for gender and group size. In addition, we will make use of Maximum likelihood estimators to account for missing data. 

To further explore the effects of peer victimization and peer status on physical health symptoms, we will make use of autoregressive multilevel models. Specifically, we will test if peer victimization and peer status on a previous time point influence physical health symptoms at the following time point (-1 lagged effects).

outliers.value: If needed, highly skewed variables (e.g., within person mean levels of peer victimization) will be (log-) transformed and extreme outliers (i.e., > 3 SD from the mean) will be winsorized to the highest value in the distribution.

dependent.value:
Dependent variable (assessed at all 4 time points) 
Physical health symptoms. Physical health symptoms were measured with 6 items. The first item assessed general health (“ In general you could say your health is?”) on a 5 point Likert scale that ranged from 1= bad to 5= excellent. The other five items assessed somatic symptoms and sleep quality. Somatic symptoms included headache, stomachache, loss of appetite and fatigue experienced in the last month. An example item is “In the past months, how many times did you have headaches?” that could be answered with ‘never (1 on the Likert scale), almost never, sometimes, often or very often (5 on the Likert scale)’. Sleep quality was assessed with the item “How would you describe your sleep quality in the past month?” This item could be answered on a 4 point Likert scale that ranged from 1= very bad to 4= very good.  
Because the somatic and sleep items were assessed on different metrics, we will make use of the proportion of maximum scaling (“POMS”) method (Little, 2013) before combining all items in one overall scale. This method transforms each scale to a metric from 0 (=minimal possible) to 1 (=maximum possible), by first making the scale range from 0 to the highest value, and then dividing the scores by the highest value. POMS = [(observed − minimum)/(maximum − minimum)]. Finally, a physical health score will be computed by averaging the scores of the six items (general health, somatic symptoms and sleep quality). Internal consistency of the physical health construct will be assessed with Cronbach’s alpha. 

Independent variables (assessed at all 4 time points)
Peer victimization was measured with the Revised Peer Experiences Questionnaire (RPEQ; Prinstein et al., 2001) including items of overt, relational and reputational peer victimization. This measure consists of thirteen statements (e.g. ‘A peer hit, kicked or pushed me in a mean and harmful way’) that were answered on a five point Likert scale from 1 (=never) to 5 (=a few times a week). A total peer victimization score will be computed at each time point by averaging across the 13 items, with higher scores indicating higher levels of peer victimization. 

Peer preference was measured with a peer nomination procedure. Adolescents nominated an unlimited number of same- and cross-gender peers within their grade whom they “like the most” (= acceptance) and “like the least” (= rejection; Coie & Dodge, 1982). To ensure anonymity, adolescents were provided with a roster including all classmates and were asked to report the numbers associated with the classmates they wished to nominate on a separate questionnaire. We used the raw number of total nominations each participant received because in this study grade size was similar for the two schools and standardization within schools would eliminate information of between person differences across schools (Nezlek, 2012; Velásquez et al., 2013). A peer preference score was computed by subtracting the “liked least” nominations from the “liked most” nominations (Cillessen & Bukowski, 2018).

Peer popularity was measured with the same peer nomination procedure as peer preference using the items “most popular” (=popularity) and “least popular” (=unpopularity). As for peer preference, we used the raw number of total nomination each participant received. A peer popularity score was computed by subtracting the “least popular” nominations from the “most popular” nominations (Cillessen & Bukowski, 2018).

conditions.value: This is an observational study; therefore it does not include any (experimental) condition

hypothesis.value:
Research question. This study aims to examine the unique, interactive and cumulative (within-person) effects of peer stressors (e.g., types of peer status and peer victimization) on physical health symptoms. Table 1 presents an overview of the expected associations for all models that will be tested. 
Importantly, hereby we formulate different hypotheses for two distinct types of peer status (i.e., peer preference and peer popularity), which could have different associations with physical health symptoms. In the unique-effect model, , we expect that low levels of peer preference would be associated with high levels of physical health symptoms (see de Bruine et al., 2019; Delfabbro et al., 2019; Temcheff et al., 2011). However, little research has examined the associations between peer popularity and health outcomes and existing findings are mixed. Therefore, we expect a quadratic association between peer popularity and physical health symptoms, based on work suggesting that both low and high levels of peer popularity may be stressful and pose risk for adjustment (e.g., Prinstein et al., 2011; Schwartz & Gorman, 2011). In addition, we will explore an interaction-effect model, as it could be that the two types of peer status interact with one another to predict physical health symptoms. For example, it may be the case that those adolescents with high levels of peer popularity but low levels of peer preference are at highest risk for physical health complaints. Finally, we will test a cumulative risk model (Evans et al., 2013), according to which we expect that adolescents who experience multiple peer stressors (e.g., peer victimization and low peer preference) will report the most physical health symptoms.

To further explore the effects of peer victimization, peer preference and peer popularity on physical health symptoms we will examine not only within-person within-time associations but we will also explore whether these peer stressors influence physical health symptoms over time (i.e., -1 lagged effects).

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.
registration_responses.name: Peer stressors and physical health symptoms during adolescents
registration_responses.other: Although no study has been published using this dataset yet, data on peer victimization and somatic symptoms have been analyzed and presented at the European Association for Research on Adolescence (EARA )biennial meeting in 2018 (de Bruine et al., 2018). These analyses indicated that peer victimization is associated with somatic symptoms at both the between- and the within-person level. However, it should be noted that the current physical health outcome is different than the one previously examined, as sleep quality and a general health item  will be added to the overall outcome construct of physical health symptoms. For peer preference and peer popularity no associations were previously explored or analyzed.
registration_responses.sample:
Data from this study will be drawn from a larger longitudinal project aimed at examining the effects of peer experiences on adolescents’ immune system functioning and health outcomes. This project consists of a multi-wave design that includes 4 time points, with approximately 6 months between consecutive assessments. Data collection begun in November/December 2016 (Time 1), when adolescents were in the fall of the first year of secondary school, and ended in June 2018 (Time 4), just before the end of the second year of secondary school. Approximately half of the targeted adolescents (n = 216) took part in the study at Time 1; retention rate between consecutive assessments was high (> 90%). Adolescents who did not participate at Time 1 of the study add the opportunity to join the study at Time 2, 3 or 4. For this study, adolescents were included if they participated in at least one of the four waves. This resulted in an analytic sample of 233 adolescents who at baseline were approximately 12 years old.
Sample size of the larger longitudinal project was based on a priori power calculation. This calculation indicated that a sample size of 200 would provide 80% power at an alpha level of 0.5% to detect significant effects, including moderating effects, at a medium effect size.
registration_responses.analyses:
Data cleaning and preparation. To examine within-person associations, before conducting the analyses the study variables will be transformed in the following way. First, within-person mean (Level 2) peer victimization, peer preference and peer popularity will be defined as an adolescent unique sample-standardized person mean across all four assessments. Second, within-person deviations in (Level 1) peer victimization, peer preference and peer popularity will be calculated as a given assessment’s value minus an adolescent’s unique person mean across all assessments divided by the adolescent’s unique standard deviation (i.e., person-standardized). Eventually, the study variables will be inspected to examine their distribution and the presence of (extreme) outliers. If needed, highly skewed variables (e.g., within person mean levels of peer victimization) will be (log-) transformed and extreme outliers (i.e., > 3 SD from the mean) will be winsorized to the highest value in the distribution. 

Main research questions. 
We will use a multilevel modeling approach to examine all research questions.
 
To examine the unique associations of peer victimization, peer preference and peer popularity on physical health (i.e., unique-effect models), we will specify 2 multivariate multilevel regression models with time at level 1 and person at level 2. First, we will predict physical health by between (e.g., within-person mean peer victimization), and within person (e.g., within-person deviations over time of peer victimization) levels of peer victimization, peer preference and peer popularity (Model 1). Second, we will examine a quadratic trend of peer popularity (Model 2). 

Subsequently, to explore whether peer preference interacts with peer popularity (i.e., interaction-effect model; Model 3),we will add the interaction term between the two types of peer status at both the between and within level (note that in this model, the quadratic effect of peer popularity will not be included)

Finally, to test a cumulative risk model we will use peer victimization, peer acceptance, rejection and unpopularity as risk variables to create a cumulative risk metric score. We will not include peer popularity in the cumulative score, as it remains unclear to what extent  high levels of peer popularity is a risk factor/stressor (this will be explored in Model 2 ). In line with research on cumulative risk (Evans et al., 2013) each risk variable will be dichotomized to reflect either absence (= “0”) or presence (=“1”) of the peer stressor. With regard to peer victimization, in line with previous research (Oldenburg et al., 2015; Solberg & Olweus, 2003) adolescents will be classified as victims (= “1”) when they score 3 or higher on at least 1 experience of peer victimization (i.e., one of the 13 items); adolescents who score 1 (= “never”) or 2 (“one/two times”) will be classified as not victimized. With this approach, adolescents who are exposed to one or more peer victimization form at least three times a month will be classified as victims. For peer acceptance adolescents will be classified as experiencing risk (i.e., “1”) if their scores fall at or below the 25th percentile (reflecting 0/1 nominations). For peer rejection and peer unpopularity adolescents will be classified as experiencing risk (i.e., “1”) if their scores are above the 75th percentile (reflecting 2 or more nomination; Gerard & Buehler, 2004; Hebron et al., 2017). 

All models will be adjusted for gender and group size. In addition, we will make use of Maximum likelihood estimators to account for missing data. 

To further explore the effects of peer victimization and peer status on physical health symptoms, we will make use of autoregressive multilevel models. Specifically, we will test if peer victimization and peer status on a previous time point influence physical health symptoms at the following time point (-1 lagged effects).

attributes.title: Basel III & Its Impact on European Banks
attributes.description: The core of the research lies in investigating if it’s really going to be a simplistic and practical process for European banks to integrate Basel III into their organization

q1.value: Basel III & Its Impact on European Banks

q3.value:
During the financial crisis loopholes of the Basel II implementation came to light. This caused major banks around the world, especially in the United States and Europe, to close down successively. Just when people were wondering, “What’s next?”, Basel III was introduced. Basel III attracted a lot of attention globally causing individuals and firms to do research on it.
Media and reports led people to believe that banks had somewhat recovered from the financial crisis and that they were holding enough capital to meet Basel III requirements easily. However, is this really true? What about the European Banks who are still facing the sovereign debt crisis? Have they really recovered?
These unanswered questions motivated us to undertake this topic. Moreover, this research will help individuals and investors to get a glimpse of the current European banking industry position.
The core of the research lies in investigating if it’s really going to be a simplistic and practical process for European banks to integrate Basel III into their organization

q4.value: In light of what is mentioned above we aim to demonstrate that European banks do not have enough capital to meet the Basel III requirements.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q1.value: PERFORMANCE BENCHMARKING MODELS; MEASURING THE EFFECT OF BRANCHES OR BRANCH LESS BANKING (BB) PERFORMANCE IN PAKISTAN BY USING DATA ENVELOPMENT ANALYSIS

q3.value:
The purpose of this study is to investigate the performance benchmarking, measures branches, branchless banking performance in Pakistan by using data envelopment analysis. DEA, primarily, takes into account the input and output gears of a decision-making unit (DMU) to calculate their performance between 0 and 1. The estimated result shows that five banks are relatively efficient when their efficiency is measured in terms of ‘constant return to scale’ and nine banks are relatively efficient when their efficiency is measured in terms of variables return to scale’. Via enhanced managing of working expenses, advances, assets and by improving banking asset operations, the less capable banks can fruitfully endorse resource utilization efficiency.
Keywords:
Bench marking, Branch less banking, Efficiency, virtual effectiveness, level effectiveness, Data envelopment analysis, Bank branches efficiency, expansion expertise

q4.value: The purpose of this thesis is to enhance the boundaries of knowledge and to investigate the performance benchmarking measure branches and branchless banking performance in Pakistan by using data envelopment analysis. The major objective of the study is to expand an effectual model for measuring the virtual competence and attainable expansion expertise of chosen bank branches by analyzing their competencies and insufficiency through submission of Data Envelopment Analysis. Also, the study is to determine the production and effectiveness features of bank branches and observe that how the level of efficiency is definite by dimension of chosen branches and to determine and contrast the efficiency of banks of Pakistan, via BCC model and CCR model of Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) for the basis of classifying the banks as well-organized and less efficient banks.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Benchmarking software is able to be used to systematize huge and multifaceted amounts of information. Software posts can enlarge the perception of benchmarking and aggressive investigation by allowing persons to grip such big and multifaceted amounts or strategies. Such tackle hold up dissimilar kinds of benchmarking and can decrease the costs drastically.
Metric benchmarking
There are two well-known forms of quantitative analysis used in metric benchmarking are data envelope analysis (DEA) and regression analysis. DEA estimates the expenditure intensity a well-organized firm should be capable to attain in a particular marketplace. In infrastructure regulation, DEA can be used to reward companies/operators whose costs are near the efficient frontier with extra earnings. Regression analysis approximates what the standard firm should be capable to attain. Through regression analysis, firms that performed better than average can be rewarded while firms that performed worse than average can be punished. Such benchmarking learns are used to create measure comparisons, tolerating outsiders to evaluate the performance of operators in a business. Superior statistical techniques, plus stochastic frontier analysis, has been worn to identify high and weak performers in industries, together with submissions to schools, hospitals, water utilities, and electric utilities.
There is an increasing concern among organizations to study level of efficiency with which they work relative to their competitors. Traditional performance measurement system provides a very unbalanced picture of performance that can lead managers to miss important opportunities for improvement. The most common methods of comparison or performance evaluation were regression
11
analysis and stochastic frontier analysis. These measures are often inadequate due to the multiple inputs and outputs related to different re-sources, activities and environmental factors. Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) provides a means of calculating apparent efficiency levels with in a group of organizations.
